channel.title: Latin American perspectives II
channel.description:
A series of lectures featuring Dr. C. Harvey Gardiner, professor of history at Southern Illinois University, about current Latin American problems and their historical setting.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: Program 27: Brazil South
item.dc:creator: Southern Illinois University at Carbondale
item.dc:subject: NAEB Regions III & IV: The Upper Midwest

item.title: Program 25: The Autobiography of a Runaway Slave
item.dc:creator: Southern Illinois University at Carbondale
item.dc:subject: Sociology

item.title: Program 24: Why Peron Came to Power
item.dc:creator: Southern Illinois University at Carbondale
item.dc:subject: NAEB Regions III & IV: The Upper Midwest

item.title: Program 17: Mexico: The Struggle for Modernity
item.dc:creator: Southern Illinois University at Carbondale
item.dc:subject: NAEB Regions III & IV: The Upper Midwest

item.title: Program 11: The Prehistory of the Tehuacan Valley: Environment and Subsistence
item.description: This episode considered "Environment and Subsistence," the first volume of the series The Prehistory of the Tehuacan Valley, focusing on the study of the rise of agriculture in prehistoric Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Southern Illinois University at Carbondale
item.dc:subject: Tehuac√°n River Valley (Mexico)

item.title: Program 8: The Dynamic of Mexican Nationalism by Frederick C. Turner
item.description: In this program Dr. Gardiner discusses The Dynamic of Mexican Nationalism by Frederick C. Turner, which considers the role of nationalism in Mexican culture and politics before and after the revolution of 1910.
item.dc:creator: Southern Illinois University at Carbondale
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Program 6: The Latin American Middle Class
item.description: This program examined the thesis of an essay from Charles Wagley's The Latin American Tradition : Essays on the Unity and the Diversity of Latin American Culture: that the Latin American middle class population is caught up in a dilemma between its liberal democratic ideals and the realities involved in the extension of liberal democracy, between a desire to extend the benefits of modern technology to the whole body politic and the terrible cost of doing so.
item.dc:creator: Southern Illinois University at Carbondale
item.dc:subject: U.S. Politics

item.title: Program 2: Human Fertility in Latin America by Stykos
item.description: This program looked at Human Fertility in Latin America by J. Mayone Stykos, which examined the cultural and sociological forces behind the region's population explosion.
item.dc:creator: Southern Illinois University at Carbondale
item.dc:subject: Sociology

item.title: Program 15: Latin America and the Caribbean
item.dc:creator: Southern Illinois University at Carbondale
item.dc:subject: NAEB Regions III & IV: The Upper Midwest

item.title: Program 22: The Economic Transformation of Cuba
item.dc:creator: Southern Illinois University at Carbondale
item.dc:subject: Sociology

item.title: Program 30:: Intervention and Revolution
item.dc:creator: Southern Illinois University at Carbondale
item.dc:subject: NAEB Regions III & IV: The Upper Midwest

item.title: Program 31: Royal Government in Colonial Brazil
item.dc:creator: Southern Illinois University at Carbondale
item.dc:subject: NAEB Regions III & IV: The Upper Midwest

item.title: Program 7: In the First of the Revolution by Jose Iglesias
item.description: This program explored In the First of the Revolution: Life in a Cuban Country Town by Jose Iglesias, which concentrated on the cultural aspects of the Cuban revolution.
item.dc:creator: Southern Illinois University at Carbondale
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Program 10: Marxism in Latin America, ed. by Louis E. Aguilar
item.description: This program commented on the book Marxism in Latin America, edited by Louis E. Aguilar, which featured a collection of commentaries and quotations on Marxism's history and impact in Latin America.
item.dc:creator: Southern Illinois University at Carbondale
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Program 9: San Juan Bautista: Gateway to Spanish Texas by Robert Weddel
item.description: Dr. Gardiner discusses Robert Weddell's San Juan Bautista: Gateway to Spanish Texas, which told the history of the San Juan Bautista del R√≠o Grande mission, located at the present-day site of Guerrero in Coahuila, Mexico, which was built by the Spanish in the 17th century to control access to Texas and the southwest.
item.dc:creator: Southern Illinois University at Carbondale
item.dc:subject: Texas--History--To 1846

item.dc:subject: Student movements

item.title: Program 1: The Politics of Exile by Paul H. Lewis
item.description: This program considered The Politics of Exile by Paul H. Lewis, which focused on the Febrerista party of Paraguay, which had operated in exile for twenty-seven of the thirty years of its existence.
item.dc:creator: Southern Illinois University at Carbondale
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Program 5: Organized Labor and the Mexican Revolution Under Lazaro Cardenas
item.description: This program looked at Joe C. Ashby's book, Organized Labor and the Mexican Revolution Under Lazaro Cardenas, which focused on the pro-labor and agriculture presidency of L√°zaro C√°rdenas del R√≠o from 1934-1940.

item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Program 3: The Triumph by John Kenneth Galbraith
item.description: This program covered The Triumph by John Kenneth Galbraith, a satirical novel describing the U.S. response to a political rebellion in a fictional Latin American country.

item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Program 4: Haiti and the Dominican Republic by R.W. Logan
item.description: This program considered Haiti and the Dominican Republic by R.W. Logan, which covered the U.S.' historic concern about political stability in the region.
